questions.question: How many players are there on a football (soccer) team on the field?
questions.explanation: A football team has 11 players on the field.

questions.question: What is the duration of a standard football match?
questions.explanation: A standard football match lasts 90 minutes (two 45-minute halves).

questions.question: What does FIFA stand for?
questions.explanation: FIFA stands for Fédération Internationale de Football Association.

questions.question: Which country won the first FIFA World Cup in 1930?
questions.explanation: Uruguay hosted and won the inaugural World Cup in 1930.

questions.question: What is the maximum number of substitutions allowed in most competitions today (excluding special rules)?
questions.explanation: Most modern competitions allow up to five substitutions.

questions.question: Which position is primarily responsible for preventing goals?
questions.explanation: The goalkeeper's main role is to stop the ball from entering the net.

questions.question: What is given for a serious foul inside the penalty area?
questions.explanation: A direct foul by the defense inside the box results in a penalty kick.

questions.question: How many referees use VAR in the video booth?
questions.explanation: Typically, a VAR and an assistant VAR operate together in the booth.

questions.question: Which club has won the most UEFA Champions League titles?
questions.explanation: Real Madrid holds the record for the most Champions League titles.

questions.question: What is an offside offense?
options: A player ahead of both ball and second-last opponent at pass
A goalkeeper handling outside the box
questions.explanation: Offside occurs when the attacker is closer to the opponent’s goal than both the ball and the second-last defender at the moment the ball is played, and becomes involved in active play.

questions.question: How many yards is the penalty spot from the goal line?
questions.explanation: The penalty mark is 12 yards (10.97 m) from the goal line.

questions.question: Which team is nicknamed the 'Three Lions'?
questions.explanation: The England national team is known as the 'Three Lions'.

questions.question: What color card can a referee show to send a player off?
questions.explanation: A red card results in a player being sent off.

questions.question: Which tournament is played every four years and features national teams?
questions.explanation: The FIFA World Cup is contested by national teams every four years.

questions.question: What is a hat-trick?
questions.explanation: A hat-trick is when a player scores three goals in one match.

questions.question: Which position often wears number 9?
questions.explanation: The traditional number 9 is the center forward/striker.

questions.question: Which country hosts the 'El Clásico' rivalry clubs?
questions.explanation: El Clásico features Real Madrid and Barcelona from Spain.

questions.question: What is stoppage time?
options: Time added to compensate for stoppages
questions.explanation: Stoppage (added) time compensates for delays during each half.

questions.question: How many minutes is each extra-time period in knockout matches?
questions.explanation: Extra time is two periods of 15 minutes each.

questions.question: Which body writes the Laws of the Game?
questions.explanation: The International Football Association Board (IFAB) maintains the Laws of the Game.

questions.question: How many points is a three-point field goal worth in basketball?
questions.explanation: A successful shot from beyond the three-point line is worth 3 points.

questions.question: How long is one quarter in the NBA?
questions.explanation: In the NBA, each quarter lasts 12 minutes.

questions.question: How many players from one team are on the court at a time?
questions.explanation: Each team fields five players on the court.

questions.question: What is traveling?
questions.explanation: Traveling is moving illegally without dribbling the ball.

questions.question: Which shot is worth one point?
questions.explanation: A free throw is worth one point.

questions.question: What does NBA stand for?
questions.explanation: NBA stands for National Basketball Association.

questions.question: What is the shot clock duration in the NBA?
questions.explanation: The NBA uses a 24-second shot clock.

questions.question: Which violation resets the backcourt count?
questions.explanation: Calling a time-out can reset counts depending on context; the eight-second violation occurs if you don't advance by 8 seconds.

questions.question: What is a triple-double?
questions.explanation: A triple-double means at least 10 in three statistical categories (points, rebounds, assists, etc.).

questions.question: Which line defines a three-point shot?
questions.explanation: Shots beyond the three-point arc are worth three points.

questions.question: What is goaltending?
options: Blocking after a downward flight or on the rim
questions.explanation: Goaltending occurs when a defender interferes with the ball on its downward trajectory or above the cylinder.

questions.question: How many personal fouls disqualify an NBA player?
questions.explanation: Six personal fouls disqualify a player in the NBA.

questions.question: What is a pick-and-roll?
options: Offensive action with screen and roll
questions.explanation: A pick-and-roll is an offensive play where a screener rolls to the basket after setting a screen.

questions.question: What is the mid-court line violation when moving backward?
questions.explanation: Once the offense crosses mid-court, returning the ball to the backcourt is a violation.

questions.question: How many time-outs are allowed per NBA game (team, regulation)?
questions.explanation: Teams are allotted seven time-outs in regulation; rules may vary over seasons.

questions.question: Which position usually brings the ball up?
questions.explanation: The point guard typically initiates the offense and brings the ball up.

questions.question: What is a technical foul?
questions.explanation: Technical fouls cover sportsmanship or procedural violations.

questions.question: How many seconds can an offensive player stay in the key (NBA)?
questions.explanation: The offensive three-second rule limits time in the paint.

questions.question: What is a flagrant foul?
questions.explanation: A flagrant is excessive or unnecessary contact; can be type 1 or 2.

questions.question: Which trophy is awarded to the NBA champions?
questions.explanation: The NBA champions receive the Larry O'Brien Trophy.

questions.question: How many players are on the court per volleyball team?
questions.explanation: A volleyball team has 6 players on the court.

questions.question: What is the libero's primary role?
questions.explanation: The libero is a defensive specialist who cannot attack above the net height.

questions.question: How many points are needed to win a set (rally scoring)?
questions.explanation: Most indoor sets are played to 25 points, win by two.

questions.question: How many sets are typically played in a match (indoor)?
questions.explanation: Indoor volleyball is usually best of five sets.

questions.question: What is a 'block'?
options: A defensive play at the net
questions.explanation: A block stops or deflects an attack at the net.

questions.question: What is a 'dig'?
options: A defensive save of an attack
questions.explanation: A dig is a defensive save of an opponent's attack.

questions.question: What is the maximum number of touches allowed per team before sending the ball over?
questions.explanation: A team may contact the ball up to three times (not counting a block).

questions.question: What is a 'setter' responsible for?
questions.explanation: The setter organizes the offense and delivers sets to attackers.

questions.question: Which line separates front and back row players?
questions.explanation: The attack line (10-foot/3-meter) separates front and back rows.

questions.question: How many points is the fifth set usually played to?
questions.explanation: The deciding fifth set is typically to 15 points, win by two.

questions.question: What is a 'kill'?
options: A successful attack resulting in a point
questions.explanation: A kill is an attack that results directly in a point.

questions.question: What is a 'rotation' in volleyball?
questions.explanation: Teams rotate positions clockwise after winning the serve.

questions.question: What is a 'foot fault'?
options: Stepping on the center line under the net
questions.explanation: A foot fault is stepping over the service or center line illegally.

questions.question: How many substitutions are usually allowed per set (FIVB)?
questions.explanation: FIVB rules typically allow 6 subs per team per set; NCAA allows 15. We'll accept 12 as common club variations—rules vary.

questions.question: What is 'serve receive'?
questions.explanation: Serve receive is the formation and action to pass the opponent's serve.

questions.question: Which contact is usually second in the sequence pass-set-attack?
questions.explanation: The typical sequence is pass, set, then attack.

questions.question: What is 'beach volleyball' team size?
questions.explanation: Beach volleyball teams consist of two players.

questions.question: Can the libero serve in international play?
questions.explanation: Libero may serve in one rotation in some rule sets; FIVB allows one position.

questions.question: What is a 'double contact'?
options: Two consecutive contacts by the same player illegally
questions.explanation: Double contact is when the same player contacts the ball twice in succession illegally (except on a block).

questions.question: What does 'out' mean when the ball lands outside the boundary lines?
options: Point to the team that did not touch last
questions.explanation: If the ball lands out untouched, the point goes to the team that did not touch it last.

questions.question: What is a serve that the opponent cannot touch called?
questions.explanation: An ace is an untouched serve that wins the point.

questions.question: What is the term for 40–40?
questions.explanation: Deuce is 40–40; one must win two points in a row from deuce.

questions.question: How many sets are needed to win a women's Grand Slam match (most events)?
questions.explanation: Women's singles are best-of-three sets at Grand Slams.

questions.question: What surface is the French Open played on?
questions.explanation: Roland Garros is played on clay courts.

questions.question: What does 'love' mean in tennis scoring?
questions.explanation: Love means zero in tennis scoring.

questions.question: What is a tie-break usually played to?
questions.explanation: Standard tie-breaks are to 7 (win by two).

questions.question: Which stroke is typically hit with the non-dominant side facing the net?
questions.explanation: The backhand is hit with the non-dominant side toward the net.

questions.question: What is a 'let' on serve?
questions.explanation: A let is a serve that clips the net and lands in; the point is replayed.

questions.question: How many tries do you get for a legal serve?
questions.explanation: A player gets two attempts to land a legal serve.

questions.question: Which Grand Slam is played on grass?
questions.explanation: Wimbledon is the only Grand Slam on grass.

questions.question: What is a 'double fault'?
options: Two faults in a row on a point
questions.explanation: A double fault occurs when both serve attempts are faults.

questions.question: What is 'break point'?
options: Receiver can win the game on this point
questions.explanation: Break point occurs when the receiver can win the game on the next point.

questions.question: What does 'advantage in' mean?
questions.explanation: Advantage in (Ad-In) indicates the server won the point after deuce.

questions.question: Which stroke is hit before the ball bounces?
questions.explanation: A volley is struck out of the air before the bounce.

questions.question: What is 'baseline' play?
options: From the back of the court
questions.explanation: Baseline play refers to rallies from near the back line.

questions.question: What is a 'drop shot'?
options: Soft shot just over the net
questions.explanation: A drop shot is lightly hit to land just over the net.

questions.question: What does 'seed' mean?
questions.explanation: Seeds are ranked positions in a tournament draw to separate top players.

questions.question: Which ball change interval is common in pro matches?
questions.explanation: Balls are commonly changed every 9 games in pro matches (after the first 7).

questions.question: What is 'Hawkeye' used for?
questions.explanation: Hawkeye provides electronic line-calling and replays.

questions.question: What is the minimum number of games to win a set (without tie-break)?
questions.explanation: A set is typically won at 6 games with at least a two-game margin.

questions.question: Which stroke is swum on the back?
questions.explanation: Backstroke is swum on the back with alternating arm action.

questions.question: How many individual medley strokes are there?
questions.explanation: INDIVIDUAL MEDLEY uses butterfly, backstroke, breaststroke, and freestyle.

questions.question: Which stroke starts with a dive in backstroke events?
questions.explanation: Backstroke starts in the water, not with a dive.

questions.question: What is a 'flip turn'?
questions.explanation: A flip turn is a somersault turn used in freestyle and backstroke.

questions.question: What equipment helps with leg training?
questions.explanation: A kickboard is used to isolate and train the legs.

questions.question: What does a 'DQ' mean?
questions.explanation: DQ means the swimmer was disqualified for a rules infraction.

questions.question: How many swimmers are in a standard relay team?
questions.explanation: Relays use four swimmers per team.

questions.question: Which stroke requires a symmetrical dolphin kick?
questions.explanation: Butterfly uses a simultaneous arm pull with dolphin kick.

questions.question: Which stroke requires a simultaneous arm and leg action with a glide?
questions.explanation: Breaststroke uses a simultaneous pull, kick, and glide.

questions.question: What is the Olympic pool length?
questions.explanation: Long-course Olympic pools are 50 meters long.

questions.question: What is 'negative split'?
questions.explanation: A negative split means swimming the second half faster than the first.

questions.question: Which lane is usually fastest in finals?
questions.explanation: Lane 4 typically goes to top seed; pool speed varies, though.

questions.question: How many strokes are allowed underwater after the start in butterfly/backstroke?
questions.explanation: Swimmers may go up to 15 meters underwater in fly/back/free.

questions.question: What does 'tap' refer to in relays?
options: Touch on the wall for exchange
questions.explanation: A touch at the wall triggers the next swimmer's start in a relay.

questions.question: What is a 'pull buoy' used for?
questions.explanation: A pull buoy supports the legs so swimmers can focus on arm stroke.

questions.question: What is 'drafting' in open water?
questions.explanation: Drafting reduces energy by following in another swimmer's wake.

questions.question: How many individual Olympic distances are common in freestyle?
questions.explanation: Olympic freestyle includes 50, 100, 200, 400, 800 (women), 1500 (men/women).

questions.question: What is the stroke order in the medley relay?
questions.explanation: Medley relay order: Backstroke, Breaststroke, Butterfly, Freestyle.

questions.question: Which tool measures lap times on the scoreboard?
questions.explanation: Electronic touchpads register touches to time finishes and splits.

questions.question: What color cap must all Olympic swimmers wear if provided by organizers?
questions.explanation: Swimmers wear caps provided by organizers with required branding.

questions.question: What is the standard length of an outdoor track lap?
questions.explanation: A standard outdoor track is 400 meters per lap.

questions.question: Which event includes 100 m, long jump, shot put, high jump, and 400 m (day 1)?
questions.explanation: The decathlon (men) includes these events over two days.

questions.question: What is a relay exchange zone length?
questions.explanation: The exchange zone in sprint relays is 20 meters.

questions.question: Which field event uses a fiberglass pole?
questions.explanation: Pole vault uses a flexible pole to clear a bar.

questions.question: How many hurdles are in the 110 m hurdles?
questions.explanation: The 110 m hurdles has 10 hurdles.

questions.question: What is the women's combined event over two days?
questions.explanation: Heptathlon is the women's two-day combined event outdoors.

questions.question: Which race is 42.195 km?
questions.explanation: The marathon distance is 42.195 kilometers.

questions.question: What do officials use to measure long jump attempts?
questions.explanation: Long jump distances are measured with tape or laser devices.

questions.question: What is false start rule in sprints?
questions.explanation: A reaction time faster than 0.1 s is considered a false start.

questions.question: Which event uses a hammer with a wire and handle?
questions.explanation: Hammer throw uses a metal ball attached to a wire and handle.

questions.question: What is the baton used in?
questions.explanation: A baton is passed between teammates in relay races.

questions.question: Which race includes barriers and water jumps?
questions.explanation: The steeplechase features hurdles and a water pit.

questions.question: What is DNF in results?
questions.explanation: DNF means the athlete did not finish the race.

questions.question: What footwear maximizes grip on track?
questions.explanation: Spikes are lightweight shoes with pins for traction.

questions.question: Which field event throws a spear-like implement?
questions.explanation: Javelin throw uses a spear-like implement.

questions.question: How many attempts are commonly allowed per throw/jump in finals?
questions.explanation: Finals often allow up to six attempts for throws/jumps.

questions.question: What is PB in athletics?
questions.explanation: PB stands for Personal Best performance.

questions.question: Which event circles 25 laps on a 400 m track?
questions.explanation: 10,000 m is 25 laps of a 400 m track.

questions.question: What is a staggered start used for?
options: Curved tracks to equalize lane distances
questions.explanation: Staggered starts equalize distance on the curve.

questions.question: Which combined event includes shot put and javelin?
questions.explanation: Both heptathlon and decathlon include the shot put and javelin.

questions.question: Which apparatus is exclusive to women's artistic gymnastics?
questions.explanation: The balance beam is a women's apparatus.

questions.question: Which apparatus is exclusive to men's artistic gymnastics?
questions.explanation: Pommel horse is used in men's artistic gymnastics.

questions.question: What does 'all-around' mean?
questions.explanation: All-around is the combined score on multiple apparatuses.

questions.question: Which apparatus uses high and low bars for women?
questions.explanation: Uneven bars have two bars at different heights for women.

questions.question: What is a 'dismount'?
options: Final skill to leave the apparatus
questions.explanation: A dismount is the final move to off-load an apparatus.

questions.question: Which code governs scoring in artistic gymnastics?
questions.explanation: The FIG Code of Points defines scoring.

questions.question: What is 'difficulty score' (D-score)?
questions.explanation: D-score reflects content difficulty; E-score reflects execution.

questions.question: Which event uses rings suspended from a frame?
questions.explanation: Still rings are a men's apparatus.

questions.question: What is 'vault'?
questions.explanation: Vault involves a sprint, springboard, and push from the table.

questions.question: What is the common floor exercise surface?
questions.explanation: A spring floor aids tumbling and safety.

questions.question: What is a 'salto'?
questions.explanation: A salto is a somersault or flip.

questions.question: What is the penalty for stepping out of bounds on floor?
questions.explanation: Stepping out incurs an execution deduction.

questions.question: What is 'team final'?
questions.explanation: The team final features best national teams from qualification.

questions.question: Which apparatus focuses on circles and flairs?
questions.explanation: Pommel horse routines emphasize circles and flairs.

questions.question: What is 'E-score'?
questions.explanation: E-score is execution-based: 10.0 minus deductions.

questions.question: What is 'connection value'?
questions.explanation: Connections of skills can earn bonus points.

questions.question: What is 'artistry' in women’s floor?
questions.explanation: Artistry covers choreography, expression, and presentation.

questions.question: Which apparatus often results in 'rip' calluses?
questions.explanation: Uneven bars can cause hand rips (calluses).

questions.question: What does FIG stand for?
questions.explanation: FIG is the world governing body for gymnastics.

questions.question: What is a 'stick' on landing?
options: No movement of feet on landing
questions.explanation: To 'stick' a landing means no step or hop after landing.

questions.question: How many minutes are in a standard professional boxing round?
questions.explanation: Professional rounds are usually 3 minutes with 1-minute rest.

questions.question: What does TKO stand for?
questions.explanation: TKO means the referee stops the fight when a boxer cannot safely continue.

questions.question: How many judges typically score a professional bout?
questions.explanation: Three ringside judges score most professional bouts.

questions.question: Which punch is thrown with the lead hand straight out?
questions.explanation: A jab is a quick, straight lead-hand punch.

questions.question: What is a 'southpaw' stance?
options: Left foot back, right hand lead
Right foot back, left hand lead
questions.explanation: Southpaw uses right hand/foot forward; left is rear power hand.

questions.question: What does KO mean?
questions.explanation: A knockout occurs when a boxer cannot rise by the count of ten.

questions.question: What is the neutral corner?
options: Designated corner for the boxer after a knockdown
questions.explanation: After a knockdown, the boxer is sent to a neutral corner.

questions.question: What equipment protects the teeth and jaw?
questions.explanation: A mouthguard protects the teeth and jaw.

questions.question: Which body part is illegal to hit?
questions.explanation: Strikes to the back of the head (rabbit punches) are illegal.

questions.question: What scoring system is commonly used?
questions.explanation: The 10-9 must system is common: winner of the round gets 10 points.

questions.question: How many ropes surround a boxing ring?
questions.explanation: A typical boxing ring is enclosed by four ropes.

questions.question: What is a 'cutman' responsible for?
questions.explanation: Cutmen manage cuts and swelling between rounds.

questions.question: What does 'reach' measure?
questions.explanation: Reach is the distance from fingertip to fingertip across arms.

questions.question: What is a 'weigh-in' for?
questions.explanation: Weigh-ins ensure fighters meet the division weight limit.

questions.question: Which punch travels in a looping horizontal arc?
questions.explanation: A hook is delivered in a horizontal arc.

questions.question: What happens after three knockdowns in one round (in some rules)?
questions.explanation: Some jurisdictions apply a three-knockdown rule resulting in a TKO.

questions.question: What is 'orthodox' stance?
questions.explanation: Orthodox stance has left hand/foot forward and right hand back.

questions.question: What does 'body shot' target?
questions.explanation: A body shot targets the torso to sap energy.

questions.question: What is a 'split decision'?
options: Two judges for one boxer, one for the other
questions.explanation: A split decision occurs when two judges score for one boxer, one for the other.

questions.question: What is a 'ring generalship'?
questions.explanation: Ring generalship is controlling the pace and position in the ring.

questions.question: What does 'dojo' mean?
questions.explanation: Dojo refers to a training hall or place of practice.

questions.question: What is a 'gi'?
questions.explanation: A gi is a traditional martial arts uniform.

questions.question: Which art focuses on throws and grappling?
questions.explanation: Judo emphasizes throws and groundwork.

questions.question: Which art is known for high, fast kicks?
questions.explanation: Taekwondo is famous for dynamic kicking techniques.

questions.question: Which belt typically signifies a beginner?
questions.explanation: White belt usually denotes a beginner.

questions.question: What does 'kumite' refer to in karate?
questions.explanation: Kumite is sparring practice.

questions.question: What is 'kata'?
questions.explanation: Kata are structured patterns of techniques.

questions.question: Which grappling art emphasizes positional control and submissions?
questions.explanation: Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu focuses on positional control and submissions.

questions.question: Which art is called 'the art of eight limbs'?
questions.explanation: Muay Thai uses fists, elbows, knees, and shins.

questions.question: What does 'ukemi' mean in judo/BJJ?
questions.explanation: Ukemi are safe falling techniques.

questions.question: What is a 'rear-naked choke' also known as?
questions.explanation: Rear-naked choke is called 'mata leão' in Portuguese.

questions.question: Which art uses forms called 'poomsae'?
questions.explanation: Taekwondo forms are known as poomsae.

questions.question: What does 'oss' express in many gyms?
questions.explanation: ‘Oss’ is a sign of respect or acknowledgment.

questions.question: Which position is dominant in BJJ?
questions.explanation: Mount is a dominant position offering control and attacks.

questions.question: What are 'katas' in karate used for?
questions.explanation: Katas encode techniques, timing, and principles.

questions.question: What is a 'black belt' generally a symbol of?
questions.explanation: A black belt indicates advanced skill; standards vary by art.

questions.question: Which weapon is associated with kendo?
questions.explanation: Kendo uses bamboo swords (shinai) simulating katana.

questions.question: What is 'gi choke'?
questions.explanation: Gi chokes use the opponent's lapel/collar to apply pressure.

questions.question: Which art emphasizes redirection of energy?
questions.explanation: Aikido emphasizes blending and redirecting force.

questions.question: What is 'sparring'?
questions.explanation: Sparring is live practice with varying intensity and rules.

questions.question: What does the word 'yoga' roughly translate to?
questions.explanation: Yoga is often translated as 'union' or 'to yoke'.

questions.question: What is 'asana'?
questions.explanation: Asana refers to physical postures in yoga.

questions.question: What is 'pranayama'?
questions.explanation: Pranayama involves breathing techniques and control.

questions.question: Which pose is also called 'Adho Mukha Svanasana'?
questions.explanation: Adho Mukha Svanasana is Downward-Facing Dog.

questions.question: What is 'savasana' typically used for?
questions.explanation: Savasana (Corpse Pose) is for deep relaxation and integration.

questions.question: Which limb of yoga is 'dhyana'?
questions.explanation: Dhyana is meditation in the eight limbs of yoga.

questions.question: What is 'namaste' commonly used for?
questions.explanation: Namaste is a respectful greeting or gesture.

questions.question: Which style links breath to movement in a flow?
questions.explanation: Vinyasa emphasizes flowing sequences coordinated with breath.

questions.question: What is 'ujjayi' breath?
questions.explanation: Ujjayi is a constricted throat breath creating an oceanic sound.

questions.question: What is 'bandha'?
questions.explanation: Bandha refers to energetic locks like mula, uddiyana, jalandhara.

questions.question: Which pose is an inversion?
questions.explanation: Bridge Pose (Setu Bandha Sarvangasana) can be mild inversion; stronger examples include Headstand.

questions.question: What is 'drishti'?
questions.explanation: Drishti is a focal gaze point to aid concentration.

questions.question: Which practice focuses on long passive holds?
questions.explanation: Yin yoga uses long holds targeting connective tissues.

questions.question: What is 'OM' considered?
questions.explanation: OM is a sacred syllable chanted in many practices.

questions.question: Which pose opens the hips deeply?
questions.explanation: Pigeon Pose (Eka Pada Rajakapotasana) opens the hips.

questions.question: What is 'asana alignment'?
questions.explanation: Alignment ensures safe, effective positioning in poses.

questions.question: What prop helps with flexibility and reach?
questions.explanation: A strap assists with reach in stretches and binds.

questions.question: What is 'nadi shodhana'?
questions.explanation: Nadi shodhana is alternate nostril breathing.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of warm-up in yoga?
questions.explanation: Warm-ups prepare the body and mind for deeper practice.

questions.question: What does 'ahimsa' represent in yoga philosophy?
questions.explanation: Ahimsa is the principle of non-violence in the yamas.
